Nano porous PtRu alloy catalyst with enhanced synergic effect for selective hydrogenation of chloronitrobenzene Yang Yang Methodology Writing – review & editing a b Jie Tang Conceptualization Writing – review & editing a b Jubo Zhang Conceptualization Writing – review & editing a Chao Liu Methodology Writing – review & editing a ⁎ Jiahui Huang Methodology Writing – review & editing a ⁎ a Dalian National Laboratory for Clean Energy, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian 116023, PR China Dalian National Laboratory for Clean Energy Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics Chinese Academy of Sciences Dalian 116023 PR China aDalian National Laboratory for Clean Energy, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian 116023, PR China b University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, PR China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100049 PR China bUniversity of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Selective hydrogenation of chloronitrobenzene (CNB) to chloroaniline (CAN) is a critical reaction for producing multiple valuable fine chemicals. Inhibiting the dechlorination is extremely vital for this reaction. In this work, we synthesize supported nano porous PtRu alloy catalyst for this catalytic reaction. The special structure of alloy catalyst, mutual-accessible Ru enriched surface and Pt enriched core, strengthens the synergic effect between Ru and Pt, thus improves the catalytic performance. As a result, 100% of o-chloronitrobenzene (o-CNB) conversion and 99.9% of o-chloroaniline (o-CAN) selectivity are achieved by the most optimal catalyst. Besides, the catalyst shows superior selectivity of o-CAN (98%) even under harsh reaction conditions such as high temperature of 150 °C and high pressure of 6 MPa. The excellent catalytic performance is also observed in selective hydrogenation of m-chloronitrobenzene (m-CNB) and p-chloronitrobenzene (p-CNB) as well. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Synergic effect Nano porous alloy Selectively hydrogenation Chloronitrobenzene Chloroaniline Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Aromatic haloamines is an important industrial intermediate product because of its application in various fields, such as dyes, drugs, herbicides, and pesticides [1]. With the increasing demand of aromatic haloamines, various methods were investigated to catalyze halogenated nitrobenzene to corresponding amine [2–4]. Selective hydrogenation of halonitroaromatics with H2 as reducing agent is the most promising one since it is environmentally friendly and atomic economic [5]. Pd [6,7], Ru [8], Pt [1,9], Au [10,11], Ag [12], Ni [13,14], and Co [15] catalysts have been applied to catalyze selective hydrogenation of chloronitrobenzene. However, the dehalogenation is a common phenomenon, and the higher reactivity of CCl bond tends to cause dechlorination [16,17]. Therefore, inhibiting side reaction to improve the selectivity of aromatic haloamines is the main challenge. Design and manipulation of desired catalysts is the key to realize selective hydrogenation of chloronitrobenzene to chloroaniline. Zhang et al. [18] used sodium polystyrenesulfonate to modify reduced graphene oxide (RGO) supported Pd catalyst, and the catalytic performance of 80% o-CNB conversion and 82% o-CAN selectivity was achieved. Hao et al. [19] chose polyurea to support Pt nanoparticles and the electron density of supported Pt nanoparticles was improved via metal-support interaction, resulting in a high o-CAN selectivity of 99%. Multi-metal catalyst is also used to catalyze selective hydrogenation of chloronitrobenzene. Compared with monometallic Mo catalyst, CoMo catalyst showed a higher o-CNB conversion (57.5% for Mo catalyst versus 89.8% for CoMo catalyst). [20] The addition of La to CoMo catalyst further improved selectivity of o-chloroaniline from 95.9% to 99.6%. Core-shell alloy catalyst is a class of nanomaterials that has received wide attention in this type of reaction owing to its unique properties. Liu et al. [21] synthesized Pt@SnO2 core-shell catalyst and found that the synergic interaction between Pt and SnO2 caused a superior catalytic performance of 98.2% of o-CNB conversion and 94.1% of o-CAN selectivity. Zhang et al. [22] prepared NiFe@NC catalyst to control the undesired hydrodehalogenation. The NiFe alloy core and the basic NC shell brought better activation abilities for reactants and higher durability of the catalyst. The catalytic performance of completely conversion of o-CNB and 99.5% of o-CAN selectivity was reached and maintained during 17 times of recycling. Although many efforts have been paid to improve the selectivity of CAN, there are still some drawbacks: high metal/chloronitrobenzene molar ratio [18,23–26] and CAN selectivity of less than 95% [18,27]. Compared with core/shell alloy catalysts, novel nano porous alloy catalyst has multiple merits: high surface area, low transfer barricade, and abundant highly exposed metal surface [28–35]. Besides, their porous structure facilitates the interaction between reaction substrate with all the components in alloy catalyst so as to strengthen the synergic effect. These advantages make nano porous alloy becoming a promising catalyst for the selective hydrogenation of CNB Hence, in this work, we designed and prepared nano porous PtRu alloy for the purpose of enhancing the synergic effect between Pt and Ru, further to improve the chloroaniline selectivity under low metal/substrate molar ratio. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation A series of nano porous PtRu alloys were prepared following our previous work [36] with some adjustments. In details, taking the preparation of nano porous Pt1Ru1 alloy as an example, 42 mg K2PtCl4 and 20 mg RuCl3·6H2O were dissolved in 20 mL deionized water. Then, 0.4 g PVP (M.W.=24,000) was added into above solution. Subsequently, 2 mL L-ascorbic acid (0.4 mol/L) was added as reducing agent. After mixing, the above mixture was put in ultrasonic pot and maintained under ultrasonication for 3 h. The powder was obtained by centrifugation and then washed by deionized water at room temperature for three times. Finally, the nano porous Pt1Ru1 alloy was dried in vacuum oven under room temperature. The other nano porous PtRu alloy, Pt3Ru1, Pt2Ru1, and Pt1Ru2 were also prepared in the same method by changing the amount of K2PtCl4 and RuCl3·6H2O accordingly. All of these nano porous PtRu alloy were denoted as PtaRub, a and b represent the molar ratio between Pt and Ru precursors during preparation process. Mesoporous Pt nanoparticle (MP) was synthesized by the method similar to our previous work [36]. 160 mg K2PtCl4 was dissolved in 40 mL deionized water. Then, 0.96 g PVP with a molecular weight of 24,000 was added. 4 ml L-ascorbic acid (0.4 mol/L) was followingly added under sonication and kept under sonication for 2.5 h. Afterwards, the above mixture was put in 45 °C water bath for 21 h. Subsequently, the powder was obtained by centrifugation and washed with 45 °C water for three times. Finally, MP was dried in vacuum oven under room temperature. In terms of preparation of supported catalyst, 13 mg as-synthesized nano porous PtRu alloy (or MP) was dispersed in 25 mL deionized water. Then, 2 g active carbon was added under stirring and kept stirring for another 4 h. The powder was obtained by centrifugation and dried in vacuum oven under room temperature. Finally, the catalyst was calcined under Air or N2 atmosphere with a ramping rate of 2 °C/min for 2 h. All the supported nano porous PtRu alloy catalysts in this work are denoted as PtaRub/AC-A (N)-X. a and b indicates the molar ratio between Pt and Ru which are used in preparation process, A (N) indicates that calcination atmosphere is Air (N2), X represents calcination temperature. Supported MP catalysts are denoted as MP/AC-A(N)-X. Since AC support is burnt out under 500 °C at the air calcination, the maximum calcination temperature under air atmosphere is 400 °C. 2.2 Characterization XRD pattern was analyzed by PANalytical Empyrean-100 with a Cu Kα X-ray source operated at 40 kV and 30 mA, and the speed of scanning was 5o/min. TEM and HRTEM images were obtained via using JEOL JEM-2100 electron microscope with a transmission voltage of 200 KV. The samples were ultrasonic dispersed in alcohol and supported on carbon film. SEM analysis was conducted on HITACHI S5500. The samples were dispersed in alcohol via sonication and followingly dropped on copper mesh. Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy analysis was conducted on SHIMADZU ICPS-8100. Sample was dissolved in aqua regia under sonication. Then, the solution was acquired by centrifugation and diluted to suitable concentration for analysis. Elemental mapping was practiced on Quanta 200F. XPS analysis was performed on Thermofisher Excalab X+ with a standard Al Kα mono-chromated flood source (150 W, pass energy = 200 eV, spot size = 500 μm). All binding energies were referenced to C1s peak at 284.8 eV of the surface adventitious carbon to correct the shift caused by charge effect. CO-pulse experiment was conducted to acquire the metal dispersion of Pt1Ru1/AC-A-400 and MP/AC-A-200. For Pt1Ru1/AC-A-400, uncalcined sample (Pt1Ru1/AC) was calcined in-situ (2 °C/min of ramping rate, 400 °C of calcination temperature, and 2 h of maintaining time) under air flow in the sample tube before CO pulse was initiated. As for MP catalyst, the in-situ calcination temperature was set as 200 °C while the remaining operation conditions were maintained as same as for PtRu catalyst. H2-D2 experiment was carried out on AutoChem 2910. The sample was firstly in situ calcined in the sample tube (atmosphere: air, calcination temperature: 200 °C for MP/AC, 400 °C for Pt1Ru1/AC, ramping rate: 2 °C/min, calcination time: 2 h). After that, the sample was cooled to 100 °C under argon atmosphere. Then, H2 (17 mL/min) and D2 pulse (0.07 mL for each pulse, repeat for 10 times) were introduced. 2.3 Catalytic performance evaluation O‑chloronitrobenzene hydrogenation in liquid phase was conducted in a 25 mL stainless steel autoclave. A certain amount of catalyst, 2.6 g o‑chloronitrobenzene and 15 mL toluene were added in the autoclave. The amount of catalyst was adjusted according to the result of ICP analysis to maintain the molar ratio between metal and o‑chloronitrobenzene is 1/1000 (ICP result is shown in Table S1). The reactor was sealed and then pressurized/depressurized under H2 flow for 5 cycles. Subsequently, the reaction temperature, pressure, and time were set. Organic sample was collected after reaction and analyzed on Agilent 7890B GC/5977A MSD by using n-dodecane as internal standard. The comparison of composition of mixture before and after reaction assures a good carbon balance. The calculation methods of conversion of o‑chloronitrobenzene (o-CNB), selectivity of o-chloroaniline (o-CAN), and selectivity of aniline (AN) are shown below: C o n v e r s i o n o f o − C N B = m o l e s o f c o n v e r t e d o − C N B i n i t i a l m o l e s o f o − C N B S e l e c t i v e t y o f o − C A N = m o l e s o f f o r m e d o − C A N m o l e s o f c o n v e r t e d o − C N B S e l e c t i v e t y o f A N = m o l e s o f f o r m e d A N m o l e s o f c o n v e r t e d o − C N B For the recycling experiment, the used catalyst was washed by 30 mL toluene for five times and then centrifugated. After that, 15 mL toluene and 2.6 g o‑chloronitrobenzene was added into autoclave for the next run. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Characterization of PtRu alloy We conducted characterizations of morphology and structure for Pt1Ru1. XRD pattern of Pt1Ru1 reveals its high crystallinity (Fig. 1 ). The diffraction peaks at about 39°, 47°, 67°, and 82° are assigned to the (111), (200), (220), and (311) facets of Pt nanoparticles with facet-centric cubic (fcc) structure, and peak positions and FWHM are summarized in Table S2. No Ru diffraction peaks is detected because of the low Ru content and no crystallinity. It is worth noting that the 2-Theta of peaks is higher than standard peaks of pure Pt, which should be attributed to the integration of Ru into Pt [37–39]. The estimated crystallite size by Scherrer equation is 4.3 nm. TEM images of Pt1Ru1 shows that the as-synthesized Pt1Ru1 has a spherical shape with porous structure and the particle size is around 150 nm (Fig. 2 a). HRTEM analysis illustrates that the Pt1Ru1 is formed by mutual-connected nanoparticles with size of 3–5 nm (Fig. 2b, c), which is in accordance with the result of XRD. Obviously, the residual PVP that covers the surface of Pt1Ru1 can also be observed in Fig. 2a (enlarged version is shown in Fig. S1). Elemental mapping analysis shows the uniform dispersion of two elements (Fig. 2e). Ru content of Pt1Ru1 was determined by ICP analysis and the result is 4.8 wt%. The low Ru content should be attributed to the low reduction potential of Ru [40] and further explains the lack of Ru peaks in XRD pattern. The lower reduction potential of Ru than that of Pt causes the fact that Ru is more difficult to be reduced than Pt. During the formation process of Pt1Ru1, Pt nuclei is first formed. After the fully reduction of Pt precursor, the Ru is then reduced. Therefore, Ru is enriched on the surface of Pt1Ru1 alloy [40,41]. 3.2 Optimization of the preparation conditions of PtRu/AC catalyst The residual PVP covers the active site of PtRu (Fig. S1), and thus further calcination treatment was carried out. As shown in Fig. 3 , uncalcined Pt1Ru1/AC showed catalytic performance with o-CNB conversion of 14.0% and o-CAN selectivity of 99.9%. After calcination in N2 atmosphere at different temperature, catalytic performance of Pt1Ru1/AC declines, giving o-CNB conversion of lower than 6.4% with o-CAN selectivity of higher than 99%. In contrast, air calcination significantly improves the catalytic performance of catalysts. Pt1Ru1/AC-A-200 and Pt1Ru1/AC-A-300 achieves higher o-CNB conversion of 21.1% and 25.0% with o-CAN selectivity of 99%. The superior catalytic performance is reached when calcination temperature is 400 °C, exhibiting completely conversion of o-CNB and o-CAN selectivity of 99.9%. According to the comparison, air calcination at 400 °C is decided as the most optimal calcination condition. We also examine the catalytic performance of Pt1Ru1 alloy under same reaction condition, the acquired o-CNB conversion and o-CAN selectivity is 17.1% and 94.7%, respectively. The similar catalytic performance between Pt1Ru1 and Pt1Ru1/AC assures that active center is Pt1Ru1 alloy. XPS analysis was conducted to investigate the reason that Pt1Ru1/AC possesses lower o-CNB conversion and higher o-CAN selectivity (Fig. S2). Obviously, Pt1Ru1/AC has higher binding energy of Pt 4f7/2 and Ru 3p3/2 than that of pure Pt1Ru1 because of the electron transfer among Pt, Ru, and AC support, which may be responsible for lower activity and higher selectivity [5,42–44]. In order to investigate the influence of Pt/Ru molar ratio on the catalytic performance, Pt3Ru1/AC-A-400, Pt2Ru1/AC-A-400, Pt1Ru1/AC-A-400, and Pt1Ru2/AC-A-400 are evaluated (Fig. 4 ). The reduction potential of Ru is great negative, and thus the higher Ru content cannot be merged into Pt nanoparticle [40]. The change of o-CNB conversion follows a volcano shape with the increase of Ru content. o-CNB conversion of 25.4% and 53.3% was obtained over Pt3Ru1/AC-A-400 and Pt2Ru1/AC-A-400. The highest o-CNB conversion of 100% was achieved over Pt1Ru1/AC-A-400. Further increasing Ru content leads to the decrease of o-CNB conversion (49.7%) over Pt1Ru2/AC-A-400. In terms of o-CAN selectivity, all of these four catalysts reach the data of higher than 98.5%. Based on the o-CNB conversion and o-CAN selectivity, Pt1Ru1/AC-A-400 shows the superior performance. Calcination at 400 °C under air atmosphere may destroy the porous structure of Pt1Ru1. Therefore, TEM analysis was conducted to check whether the porous structure of Pt1Ru1 maintains after calcination (Fig. 5 ). Comparing with uncalcined catalyst, the overall structure of calcined Pt1Ru1 at 400 °C in air is almost the same, including the size and shape (Fig. 5a, d). The small particles that constitute the whole alloy sphere can be observed in HRTEM image of Pt1Ru1/AC-A-400, similar to uncalcined catalyst (Fig. 5b, e). This indicates the porous structure of Pt1Ru1 maintains after 400 °C air calcination. The size of mutual-linked nanoparticles increases from 3 to 5 nm (before calcination) to 6–7 nm (after calcination). We also conducted XRD analysis (Fig. S3) for Pt1Ru1/AC-A-400 to investigate the estimated crystallite size of Pt1Ru1 after air calcination. The result is 7.4 nm, which is in consistent with HRTERM analysis. To intuitive observe whether the surface residual PVP is removed after 400 °C air calcination, we compared the SEM images of Pt1Ru1/AC and Pt1Ru1/AC-A-400. For uncalcined catalyst (Fig. 5c), except for the small nanoparticles on the surface, the whole external surface is smooth, and no pores or related morphology can be noticed. This indicates the residual PVP envelops the surface of alloy sphere, which is in accordance with the result of Pt1Ru1 TEM analysis (Fig. S1). In terms of Pt1Ru1/AC-A-400, totally different surface morphology is observed (Fig. 5f). The external morphology is irregular and pores can be noticed, suggesting the residual PVP is removed. Obviously, active sites are exposed via calcination at high temperature, thus boosts the catalytic performance. The information above indicates that air calcination at 400 °C can effectively remove the residual PVP which hinders substrate to contact the active sites. 3.3 Influence of the solvent on catalytic performance The effect of solvent was then investigated (Fig. 6 ). For polar protic solvent (three alcohols), the acquired o-CNB conversion is close to 100%, but the selectivity of o-CAN is lower than 65%. The selectivity of o-CAN in methanol, ethanol, and isopropanol solvent is 55.4%, 63.6%, and 53.4%, respectively. The byproducts in alcohols solvents are aniline, cyclohexylamine, and n-cyclohexylbenzenamine. As for polar aprotic solvent (acetone, acetonitrile, and DMSO), the selectivity of target product is 99.9% while the o-CNB conversion is lower than 45%. Non-polar solvent is far better than previous two counterparts. Among non-polar solvents, toluene is the most optimal option with complete conversion of o-CNB and high selectivity of o-CAN (99.9%). 3.4 Catalytic performance of Pt1Ru1/AC-A-400 under harsh conditions In order to check whether Pt1Ru1/AC-A-400 can inhibit dechlorination under various situations, we further evaluated the catalytic performance of Pt1Ru1/AC-A-400 under harsh conditions (Table 1 ). Compared with the catalytic performance of 100% o-CNB conversion and 99.9% o-CAN selectivity under normal situation (entry 1), higher reaction temperature causes a minor decrease in selectivity of o-CAN (entry 2&3). The selectivity of o-CAN is 98% under the reaction condition of 150 °C, 2 MPa, and 180 min. Increasing the reaction pressure from 2 MPa to 4 MPa and 6 MPa, the side reaction can be still controlled effectively, and the selectivity of o-CAN maintains at higher than 98% (entry 4&5). When the reaction time is prolonged to 360 min and 540 min, the acquired selectivity of o-CAN is close to 98% (entry 6&7). This indicates that Pt1Ru1/AC-A-400 possesses a superior ability of inhibiting dechlorination in o-CNB selective hydrogenation under wide range of reaction temperature and pressure. To investigate the effect of synergic interaction between Pt and Ru on the catalytic performance, we compared Pt1Ru1/AC-A-400 and MP/AC-A-X (X = 200–400). As-synthesized MP has a similar morphology to Pt1Ru1 with smaller size (Fig. S4). TEM and SEM images of Pt1Ru1/AC-A-400, MP/AC-A-200, MP/AC-A-300, and MP/AC-A-400 are compared in Fig. S5. The structure of Pt1Ru1 maintains after 400 °C calcination while MP can only tolerate 200 °C calcination. This indicates the introduction of Ru significantly improves the thermal stability of Pt1Ru1. After calcination at a higher tolerable temperature, the residual PVP of Pt1Ru1/AC can be removed more effectively so as to improve the catalytic performance. The catalytic performance of Pt1Ru1 and MP catalysts is shown in Fig. 7 a. The higher o-CNB conversion and o-CAN selectivity of Pt1Ru1 catalyst reveals the introduction of Ru can enhance the catalytic performance. XPS analysis was carried out to check the valence state of Pt and Ru in Pt1Ru1/AC-A-400. Results of the Pt 4f core level spectra are shown in Fig. 8 , the peaks at 71.13, 71.91, and 74.40 eV should be assigned to Pt 4f7/2 (Fig. 8a). According to the literature, the Pt 4f7/2 binding energy of Pt0, Pt2+, and Pt4+ is about 71.13 eV [45–47], 72.40 eV [48], and 74.90 eV [49], respectively. Therefore, Pt of Pt1Ru1/AC-A-400 is in multiple charge states, metallic state (71.13 eV), Pta+ (0<a<2, 71.91 eV), and Ptb+ (2<b<4, 74.40 eV). Peak of metallic state of Ru 3p3/2 is about 461.50 eV [50–52]. Ru 3p spectra shows the biding energy of 464.12 eV for Ru 3p3/2 (Fig. 8b), which is assigned to RuO2 and RuOx. During 400 °C calcination of Pt1Ru1/AC under air atmosphere, oxygen may oxidize Pt and Ru species, while in the following o-CNB hydrogenation at the reaction temperature of 100 °C, oxidized Pt and Ru species may be further reduced. Therefore, we conducted XPS analysis for Pt1Ru1/AC-A-400-100H (100H indicates that Pt1Ru1/AC-A-400 was further reduced by H2 flow at 100 °C for 2 h). Two peaks at 70.72 eV and 71.81 eV assigned to Pt 4f7/2 (Fig. S6a) and one peak at 462.45 eV assigned to Ru 3p3/2 (Fig. S6b) were observed over Pt1Ru1/AC-A-400-100H. Therefore, in Pt1Ru1/AC-A-400-100H, Ru is positive charge and partial Pt exists as negative species. This confirms that there exists electron transfer from Ru to Pt in Pt1Ru1/AC-A-400-100H. The molar ratio between Pt and Ru of Pt1Ru1/AC-A-400 acquired by XPS analysis is 1/2.3, suggesting the higher Ru content than that of Pt on the surface of catalyst. In contrast, ICP result (Pt/Ru molar ratio of 10.1/1) indicates the Pt is rich in tested catalyst. This distinct difference of Pt/Ru molar ratio of surface and bulk phase of catalyst demonstrates the enrichment of Ru on the surface of alloy [21,53]. The reason of excellent o-CAN selectivity over Pt1Ru1/AC-A-400 should be carefully investigated since the selectivity of target product is extremely vital for selective hydrogenation reaction. We applied Pt1Ru1/AC-A-400 and MP/AC-A-200 to catalyze o-CAN hydrodechlorination under a harsh reaction condition of 150 °C, 6 MPa, and 9 h (Fig. 7b). For Pt1Ru1/AC-A-400, the hydrodechlorination is nearly negligible, only 1.6% of o-CAN is converted to AN. In contrast, MP/AC-A-200 converts 16.1% o-CAN to AN and other byproducts. This confirms that the interaction between o-CAN and Pt1Ru1/AC-A-400 is much weaker than MP/AC-A-200, which should be attributed to Ru enriched surface of Pt1Ru1/AC-A-400, similar to previous works [26,54]. According to the literature [5], electron deficient Ru can act as electrophilic or Lewis acid site to activate N=O band in o-CNB, which should be responsible for the high o-CAN selectivity of Pt1Ru1/AC-A-400. For understanding the superior o-CNB conversion of PtRu catalyst, we conducted kinetic experiments for Pt1Ru1/AC-A-400 and MP/AC-A-200 by controlling the conversion of o-CNB at the range of 10–22% (Fig. 9 ). The activation energy for Pt1Ru1/AC-A-400 and MP/AC-A-200 is 23.4 kJ·mol−1 and 57.0 kJ·mol−1, respectively. TOF is calculated based on the metal dispersion of Pt1Ru1/AC-A-400 (14.5%) and MP/AC-A-200 (32.1%), the results are 2297 h−1 and 114 h−1. H2-D2 exchange experiment was carried out to compare the H2 dissociation ability of Pt1Ru1/AC-A-400 and MP/AC-A-200, the higher HD pulse peak area of PtRu catalyst supports that Pt1Ru1/AC-A-400 possesses stronger H2 dissociation ability (Fig. S7). The different kinetic feature, TOF value, and H2 dissociation ability of Pt1Ru1/AC-A-400 and MP/AC-A-200 indicate the synergic effect between Pt and Ru is responsible for the higher o-CNB conversion of Pt1Ru1/AC-A-400. For selectivity hydrogenation of o-CNB to o-CAN, Pt catalyst could realize high o-CNB conversion while Ru catalyst could achieve high selectivity of o-CAN. PtRu alloy catalyst could be an optimal catalyst for this reaction. However, for conventional core-shell PtRu alloy catalyst, the high o-CNB conversion and excellent o-CAN selectivity cannot be achieved at the same time. The structural constrain only allows reaction mixture to contact one of the components (Pt or Ru) [54–57]. In comparison, the porous structure of Pt1Ru1/AC-A-400 enables the reaction mixture to contact Ru enriched surface and Pt enriched core simultaneously. Because of synergy effect of Ru and Pt, the capability of Ru in activating o-CNB is improved [5], which is beneficial for o-CNB selective hydrogenation. Besides, the Ru enriched surface hinders the formation of strong interaction between o-CAN and Pt, which further leads to the high selectivity of o-CAN. Based on this synergic effect, our catalyst can achieve high conversion of o-CNB and high selectivity of o-CAN. To illustrate the advantage of Pt1Ru1/AC-A-400 catalyst, we compared the catalytic activity of our catalyst with previous works (Table 2 ). Although PVP stabilized PtRu alloy nanoparticle and Ir nanowire exhibits an excellent catalytic performance, the molar ratio between metal and substrate is low [24]. Pd catalysts show high o-CNB conversion under high metal/substrate ratio, but the selectivity of o-CAN is not higher than 92% [18,27]. Compared with Pt catalysts, Pt1Ru1/AC-A-400 exhibits similar catalytic performance under similar condition [19,21,58]. Furthermore, the Pt1Ru1/AC-A-400 catalyst displays much higher TOF value than other counterparts. Even under harsh reaction condition (150 °C of reaction temperature, 6 MPa of H2 pressure and 540 min of reaction time), Pt1Ru1/AC-A-400 still achieves excellent o-CAN selectivity of 98%. These results indicate Pt1Ru1/AC-A-400 catalyst possesses a superior catalytic performance, which should be attributed to the mutual accessible Ru enriched surface and Pt enriched core, and the common merits of nano porous metal [28–35]. 3.5 Scope of Pt1Ru1/AC-A-400 and its recycling experiment We applied our catalyst for other two kinds of chloronitrobenzene hydrogenation as well (Table 3 ). For three different chloronitrobenzene, Pt1Ru1/AC-A-400 achieves a good performance even under harsh reaction condition. As mentioned before, the selectivity of o-CAN is 97.7%. In terms of m-CNB and p-CNB, the selectivity of m-CAN and p-CAN is 89.8% and 94.3%, respectively. These results indicate nano porous Pt1Ru1/AC catalyst can achieve high selectivity of chloroaniline. Recycling experiment was conducted under the same reaction condition, the result is shown in Fig. S8. The selectivity of o-CAN remains at higher than 98% while the conversion of o-CNB decreases after being recycled for once. The deterioration of catalytic performance of Pt1Ru1/AC-A-400 after recycling should be attributed to the metal loss (Table S3) and morphology change of loaded Pt1Ru1 (Fig. S9). Further effort has been conducting in our lab to improve the stability of Pt1Ru1/AC-A-400. 4 Conclusion In this work, we synthesized supported nano porous PtRu alloy and applied it in selective hydrogenation of o-CNB. The nano porous Pt1Ru1 alloy has Ru enriched surface and Pt enriched core. This special structure enables reactants to contact Ru and Pt simultaneously so as to achieve both high o-CNB conversion and o-CAN selectivity. o-CNB conversion of 100% and o-CAN selectivity of 99.9% are achieved. The high selectivity of o-CAN is maintained even under harsh reaction condition. Besides, our catalyst can also realize high target product selectivity for other kinds of chloronitrobenzene hydrogenation under harsh reaction conditions. coredata.dc:description: Selective hydrogenation of chloronitrobenzene (CNB) to chloroaniline (CAN) is a critical reaction for producing multiple valuable fine chemicals. Inhibiting the dechlorination is extremely vital for this reaction. In this work, we synthesize supported nano porous PtRu alloy catalyst for this catalytic reaction. The special structure of alloy catalyst, mutual-accessible Ru enriched surface and Pt enriched core, strengthens the synergic effect between Ru and Pt, thus improves the catalytic performance. As a result, 100% of o-chloronitrobenzene (o-CNB) conversion and 99.9% of o-chloroaniline (o-CAN) selectivity are achieved by the most optimal catalyst. Besides, the catalyst shows superior selectivity of o-CAN (98%) even under harsh reaction conditions such as high temperature of 150 °C and high pressure of 6 MPa. The excellent catalytic performance is also observed in selective hydrogenation of m-chloronitrobenzene (m-CNB) and p-chloronitrobenzene (p-CNB) as well.
coredata.dc:title: Nano porous PtRu alloy catalyst with enhanced synergic effect for selective hydrogenation of chloronitrobenzene
